#Text=Also known as : Huaca Rajada One of the best-known cases of archaeological looting ; a Moche funerary site that was looted in 1987 ; the contents of an elite tomb were smuggled out of Peru and into various foreign collections .
#Text=The site now known as Sipán dates from approximately 1 to 700 BC and is assigned to the Moche Culture .
#Text=It is located at the village of Sipán , twenty miles east of the city of Chiclayo on Peru ’ s north coast .

#Text=The most famous archaeological objects from Sipán come from a large man-made mound called Huaca Rajada , however the term ‘ Sipán ’ is now commonly used to refer both to material from Huaca Rajada and Huaca Rajada itself .
#Text=The term ‘ Sipán ’ can also be used to refer to associated Moche archaeological areas near Huaca Rajada .
#Text=At sixty feet high , Huaca Rajada is the smallest of the three pyramids at the Sipán site .
#Text=By the mid-1980s Huaca Rajada had been minimally recorded by archaeologists and government survey but had not been archaeologically excavated .
#Text=At the time of the looting event , some archaeologists believed that the adobe mound belonged to the Chimú culture , rather than the earlier Moche culture .
#Text=Reports indicate that the spectacular Moche tombs subsequently located at Huaca Rajada were a surprise to both archaeologists and looters .
#Text=Looting of Huaca Rajada Starting in the middle of November 1986 a team of looters led by an unemployed car mechanic named Ernil Bernal began to tunnel into Huaca Rajada .
#Text=On or around 6 February 1987 the looters encountered Moche bricks in the ceiling of their trench .

#Text=Upon locating a number of gold beads between these bricks , Ernil Bernal punctured the roof of the tunnel and a torrent of gold , silver and other Moche antiquities literally poured out on top of him .

#Text=From what can be pieced together from archaeological excavation , interviews with key participants , and the results of various law enforcement investigations , the looters had located an intact elite Moche tomb .

#Text=Samuel Bernal , one of the original looters of the tomb interviewed by Atwood in 2002 , described finding a layer of hundreds of ceramic pots which were mostly destroyed while the looters searched for more valuable metal objects .
#Text=Over the next few nights the looters filled rice sacks with gold and silver artefacts which they transported to the Bernal family house .
#Text=Arguments broke out among the looters regarding how the profits from the sale of the Sipán material were going to be split .
#Text=As a result , one of the looters contacted the police who , with the aid of archaeologist Walter Alva , intervened at the site and effectively halted the looting .
#Text=The exact trail of many of the objects out of Sipán is unknown .
#Text=Items from Sipán continue to surface on the international art market , resulting in some high profile seizures or returns .
#Text=See the Encyclopedia entries on the Sipán Backflap , the Bourne Collection , and the Sipán Jewellery Seized from Sotheby ’ s for more information on Sipán material .
#Text=See the entry on the Swetnam/Drew/Kelly smuggling ring for more information on the trafficking of objects from Sipan .
